title: 108_hr2654
content: The "Rigs to Reefs Act of 2003" allows for the use of decommissioned offshore oil and gas platforms for mariculture, artificial reef, or scientific research purposes under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Secretary may authorize the use of decommissioned offshore oil and gas platforms for marine organism culture, artificial reefs, or scientific research. Liability limitations protect previous owners from costs or damages, except for specific circumstances. This does not affect other leasing or usage regulations. The Secretary of the Interior can authorize the use of decommissioned offshore oil and gas platforms for marine organism culture, artificial reefs, or scientific research. This does not impact other leasing or usage regulations. Regulations must be issued within 180 days, and a study on the effects of platform removal must be conducted within a year. The removal of offshore oil and gas platforms from the outer Continental Shelf would impact fish stocks and coral populations. The SEC. 45G provides a credit for costs related to converting offshore oil and gas platforms for culturing marine organisms. The marine organisms culturing credit under section 38 allows a 30 percent credit for qualified expenditures on converting offshore oil and gas platforms for marine organism culture. This includes costs for maintaining the platform post-decommissioning and converting it for marine organism use. The marine organisms culturing credit allows a 30 percent credit for converting offshore oil and gas platforms for marine organism culture. Taxpayers can choose to apply this credit for a taxable year by electing to do so. Amendments to section 38 of the Code include adding the marine organisms culturing credit as a new paragraph. No carryback of section 45g credit before January 1, 2004. Amendments to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003.
